Topic.Title: Amazon could match Apple's 30% selloff in a day or two of trading

Message.Msg: Any fund at any time needing to catch up on performance could liquidate with protection on and simply crush all of the other funds... That's what happened at AAPL. It will happen here. Only question is when. Have people figured out yet why the traditional correlations are breaking down (e.g. weak dollar not sending the market flying)? This time isn't like all the others... Funds that added while Bezos dumped are going to have an extraordinarily difficult time explaining it to LPs or mutual fund holders is a few months. It will go down as one of the most epic mistakes (either driven by incompetence or negligence) one could have made... This makes GMCR at 110 and CMG at 450 look like steals... Within 12 months, the issue I've been hinting at on the cost structure will rear its ugly head. When it does, Amazon will face a crisis -- either reneging on its contractual obligations to customers or changing terms in a material way. Either way, the brand will be permanently damaged and the economics flaws with be in the open for all to see. This is completely foreseeable as a very material risk and inexcusable for large holders to miss. It should and likely will be very ugly for all those who did not do appropriate fundamental due diligence... Amazon has 0% chance of growing into its valuation before the scam is exposed...

Topic.Title: A story of leadership / governance impropriety often helps thingz along

Message.Msg: In time, I suspect the Enron analogy will prove more apt than anyone currently realizes. Lots of off balance sheet financing, zero disclosure and fundamentally flawed economics. Original Prime members were very high value because of the natural selection bias. By stacking loss leader on top of loss leader, Amazon has created a very different set of selection biases that will prove disastrous when the TCO changes. In terms of disclosure, I believe Amazon has misled investors on the impact of state sales taxes but cannot prove it... yet. EBay's YOY growth dwarfed Amazon's during Cyber week. The key difference -- sales tax (Amazon surely invested more in advertising and promotion...). Amazon has skillfully evaded answering questions on the subject directly by saying "we do well in areas where we collect tax" rather than a normalized measure like sales per dollar GDP in the relevant regions. Amazon will not be able to skirt the issue much longer. The incredible increase in advertising suggests that Amazon is having to invest more overhead to generate sales now... I am perfectly comfortable waiting for the actual facts to come in. The story never measures up to reality...

Message.Title: Impact of sales tax...
Message.Msg: Anyone wonder why eBay's YOY growth rates blew away Amazon during CyberWeek, despite Amazon' entire Kindle line refresh and massive advertising campaign? Could it be that collecting taxes in the most populous states (eBay still doesn't...) actually does have an impact? Anyone wonder why Amazon always says "we perform well where we collect taxes" rather than making a normalized comparison such as "our sales intensity (Amazon revenue per $ GDP) is just as high in regions where we collect tax"?

Topic.Title: Impact of sales tax...

Message.Msg: Yahoo is censoring content, but I'll post on SA. Two issues for future posts: 1) The economics of the TV campaign 2) New Prime member economics (depends upon average order size which is likely much lower for recent Prime members due to selection biases)
